captions.text: In the early 1960s,
Dick Fosbury tried his hand at almost every sport,
but never excelled at anything,
until, at the age of 16, he turned to the high jump.
But when he couldn't compete against
the strong athletes at his college
using the standard high jump techniques of the time,
Fosbury tried to jump a different way: backwards.
Instead of jumping with his face towards the bar,
bringing each leg over in the
traditional straddle method,
he jumped with his back towards the bar.
Fosbury improved his record by over half a foot,
and left his coaches amazed
by this strange new style of high jumping.
During the next few years,
Fosbury perfected his high jump style,
won the U.S. National trials,
and assured his place in the 1968 Olympics in Mexico.
In the Olympic Games, Fosbury amazed the world
with his new technique, winning a gold metal
with an Olympic record leap of 2.24 meters.
By the next Olympic Games,
almost all of the competing of high jumpers
had adopted what came to be known as
the Fosbury Flop.
What's the secret behind the technique?
It lies in a physics concept
called the center of mass.
For every object,
we can locate the average position of all of its mass
by taking into account how the mass
is spread around the object.
For instance, the center of mass
of a flat, rectangular object of uniform density
will be in the intersection of both diagonals,
in equal distance from each corner.
We can find the center of mass for other objects
by similar calculations,
or by finding the object's balancing point,
which lies right underneath its center of mass.
Try balancing a broom by holding it
and slowly bringing your hands together until they meet.
This balancing point lies right underneath
the broom's center of mass.
We humans also have a center of mass.
When most people stand up,
their center of mass is around the belly,
but what happens to your center of mass
when you lift your hands in the air?
Your center of mass moves upwards.
It moves all the time as you move through the day,
based on how your body is positioned.
It can even move outside of your body.
When you bend forward, your center of mass
is located below your bent belly
in a place where there is no mass at all.
Weird to think about, but that's the average position
of all your mass.
Many objects' center of mass
are outside their bodies.
Think of doughnuts or boomerangs.
Now look at the Fosbury Flop, and follow the position
of the center of mass of the jumper.
The jumper runs very fast,
so he can divert his horizontal velocity
to vertical velocity, and jumps.
Wait for it...there.
Look at the jumper's center of mass
as his body bends backward.
It's below the bar.
That is the secret behind the jump.
With the old, pre-Fosbury techniques,
the jumper had to apply enough force
to lift his center of mass above the bar
by a few inches in order to clear it.
The Fosbury Flopper doesn't have to do that.
The genius of the Fosbury Flop is that the jumper
can apply the same amount of force,
but raise his body much higher than before.
That means he can raise the bar so high
that even when his center of mass
can't go any higher, his arching body can.
Fosbury's technique brought
the high jump to new heights
by splitting the jumper's body
away from his center of mass,
giving it that much more room
to clear higher and higher bars.
So the Fosbury Flop may be sports history's
only great leap forward,
that is also a great leap backward.

comments.author: mraccident

comments.text:
As to why they didn't name it after his first name, we turn to literature 
rather than physics. They obviously call it the "Fosbury Flop" because 
whoever came up with the term was aiming for artistic alliteration, both 
words beginning with "F". If they named it after his first name "Dick" they 
wouldn't have called it the "Dick Flop" because it's not alliterative. They 
might have called it the "Dick Dive". Luckily he had both a first name and 
last name that could be used alliteratively in his particular sporting 
event. If his name had been "Jones" they would have called it the "Jones 
Jump". But if his name had been "Smith" they might not have been able to 
come up with any such catchy name.﻿

comments.text: why is it better to jump backward than forward?﻿
comments.author: yukiyama87

comments.text: well that was a lot easier to understand,,
comments.author: yukiyama87

comments.text:
Ignoring the thread being 6 months old and the long comments that may or 
may not be correct, I'll answer in 1 sentence:
Jumping forwards would cause your knees/legs to pull down the bar, since 
you can't bend your knees backwards.

Even if you managed to shift your hips in time to get your legs above the 
bar, you'd crash horribly onto your face and hurt your neck.
comments.author: Mark The Gr8

comments.text:
Jumping backward has to do with both biomechanics and physics. You need to 
realize that according to high jumping rules the athletes need to jump on 
one leg. In order to achieve maximum jumping height the athletes approach 
on a diagonal, slightly curved track to gain maximum momentum. In order to 
transfer maximum momentum from running speed, the athlete will extend both 
hands and the free leg upwards raising his CM upwards in a circular motion.

Since the athlete's body is extended, not retracted flopping backwards 
provides many advantages, such as a smooth kinetic chain from extension - 
flop - clearing the bar. Also, since knees bend backwards - not forwards, 
you can achieve a much cleaner arch of the whole body jumping backwards, 
not forwards.

Front flipping would be much more difficult, seeing how 1) it's very 
difficult to front flip on one foot and 2) you would end up having to 
straighten your legs over the bar after torso has passed, instead of a 
wiggly 'whiplash' movement you can do when jumping backwards

Something else that needs to be said about the flop, is that there were 
generally lots of different height jumping styles being tried out at the 
time and during history. At the time of Fosbury Flop, thicker and softer 
mattresses (compared to sand pits and thin mattresses previously) had been 
introduced to high jumping, leading the jumper not needing to be concerned 
about a clean landing, giving much more leeway for pushing the envelope for 
technique.
comments.author: libertyisjustice

comments.text:
+jilow   I have done Physics since Jr. high.  Done it in high school and 
college.  This was one of my event in track and field.  This one is a tough 
one to answer.  Even if you have two person to test the two methods out, it 
won't prove any as the two have different abilities.  Having the same 
person do the two technique won't prove it either.  One might just perfect 
one technique better than the other.
comments.author: ArtOfBaccarat

comments.text:
I think the answer here is when you twist at the end (so you're facing 
backward) that you have to whip your head and upper body upward during the 
jump (creating more lift). However if you were running forward and stayed 
forward , you won't be able to whip your head upward (if you did you'd 
stomach would be bowed out, when you need it bowed in.)  So you'd have to 
correct it at some point near the height of your jump, slowing you down 
down the jump. If that makes sense. Haven't done physics since highschool, 
but that seems logical to me.
comments.author: jilow

comments.text:
+yukiyama87
Great question and thinking out of the box.  Maybe you can try it to see 
which way is better.  Maybe someday they'll call it the "Yukiyama flop."
comments.author: ArtOfBaccarat

comments.text:
+Elliott Collins
Why would you lose momentum when you're running forward?  You would think 
that you would lose momentum jumping on your back since you have to twist 
to have your back facing the bar.  ....  Tough question.  Just thinking 
about it, it appears jumping facing forward might give you an advantage.

Use to do this event.  We were taught to jump with back facing bar.  Would 
think it's hard because we got used to the Fosbury technique.

A few more question would be whether pushing forward or backward would give 
you a better advantage?  Also, the final kick to lift the leg at the end.
comments.author: ArtOfBaccarat

comments.text:
Good question. If you actually try it, it feels pretty intuitive, despite 
the fact that people are more bendy going forwards. A lot of the upward 
momentum in the jump comes from straightening out as you approach the bar 
and flattening out in the air. If you bend fowards, you loose a lot of that 
upward momentum and you don't have the leverage against your upper body to 
get your legs out of the way. The part they didn't animate is the second 
step in which the jumper snaps their legs upward once the center of mass is 
past the bar.
comments.author: Elliott Collins

comments.text:
+yukiyama87 I practiced that sport for about a year, and you do it 
backwards because it's easier to not loose your momentum that way
